description: From Middle English (implied in representatyfliche), from Old French representatif. By surface analysis, represent +â€Ž -ative; See representation.

adjectives.description: representative (comparative more representative, superlative most representative)

entries.meaning: Typical; having the same properties or interest as a larger group.
examples: If you took all the fools out of the legislature, it wouldn't be a representative body anymore.
Are you sure this paper is representative of your child's writing?
the representative faculty of the human imagination

entries.meaning: Someone who represents others as a member of a legislative or governing body. [from 17th c.]
examples: She served four terms as representative of her local at the national union convention.

entries.meaning: One who speaks for or acts on behalf of another in a particular (especially official) capacity. [from 17th c.]
examples: I will send a representative to work out the details of the contract.

entries.meaning: (US, politics) Specifically, a member of the United States House of Representatives. [from 18th c.]
examples: All representatives face re-election every two years.

entries.meaning: A company agent who visits potential purchasers; a salesman. [from 20th c.]
Something representing or standing for another; a symbol, an embodiment. [from 17th c.]
A member of a particular class.
Something (especially a living organism) regarded as typical of its class; a type. [from 17th c.]
